Author: revwuzhere
Content:
i am currently constructing a research proposal for my Undergraduate Thesis on Psychology Major with the following title :

"AI Art sebagai Peluang atau Ancaman? Pengaruh Perception of AI Opportunity terhadap Existential Well-Being Digital Artist, ditinjau dari Subjective Job Insecurity"

although how skyrocket the usage of AI in last year, the research abt relationship between Perception of AI Opportunity and human behavior is still considered little in term of numbers and hence why i will try to contribute the digital artist point of view and hopefully encourage the ethical use of AI Art.

as Subjective Job Insecurity role for the mediator between the relationship, i'm curious on how Perception of AI Opportunity affect Existential Well-Being indirectly via Subjective Job Insecurity.

do you guys think this research is important to do? or is there any variable i could replace of? let me know your thought or curiousity

Author: revwuzhere
Content:
me itself, believe that the usage of AI Art is commonly unethical. it is outside the scope of my re(se)arch in this topic i wanted to bring
( while i believe this research can be explored further in the future, and put an insight how ethical AI usage, proper data mining, and profesionalism AI Vendor can give digital artist a sigh of relief a.k.a affecting the well-being of the digital artist )

Author: revwuzhere
Content:
think of it like this, X (Perception of AI Opportunity) -> Y (Existential Well-Being)
"does the digital artists that have a sceptism towards AI Opportunity, lead to a fearful, insecure digital artist?"

or

"does the digital artists that know how to view AI Art as a tool and able to utilize it, affect that the state of digital artist to feel more valueable? that their existence had a meaning?"

both statement is the hypothesis i had in this topic, and if the data i collected later are accurate, that means X affect Y. 
Which can be a research further on how can we increase the Perception of AI Opportunity among the digital artists. Maybe legitimitation of artist rights would help? or AI that have digital artists consent increase the Perception of AI Opportunity itself

Author: revwuzhere
Content: now that i thought in this research, i should divide the subject characterization by their working state ( full timer / commission based ) because i believe in corporate settings, full timer digital artist integrate the usage of AI to their artwork because of tuntutan pekerjaan

Author: nthnael.san
Content: Menurutku it's an opportunity, kenapa? Artist seringkali mengalami art block dan "bingung mulai dari mana". Sedangkan AI dapat mempermudah artist untuk memulai terlebih dahulu, melakukan prototyping dan memberikan gambaran awal dikepala mereka. Ingat, AI itu cuman glorified Data Science, tanpa adanya data, maka AI gabisa ngapa2in, tanpa adanya manusia, AI gabisa ngeprompt anything good out of it. My Controversial take is, "Artist should learn how to use AI to Assist them"

Author: nthnael.san
Content: The problem that being discussed nowadays is about the ethics of how do the AI being trained. Are they "stealing" people art to train their AI? Have them got the permission from the artist? More of it, AI Artist are NOT a real artist, prompting shit into AI is NOT the same as producing art. Therefore, the main problem that needed to be discussed is actually about the Ethics of AI Art.

Author: revwuzhere
Content:
this isn‚Äôt innovation. this isn‚Äôt efficiency. this is greed, plain and brutal. executives slashing artist jobs, not to elevate creativity, but to churn out fast, cheap, soulless content. they flood the market with AI sludge, and what do we lose? not just paychecks. not just careers. we lose value itself.

why would anyone pay $200 for a human-crafted illustration when a machine vomits one up for pennies? Why commission emotion, skill, or vision when corporations can drown us in endless, hollow imitations? this isn‚Äôt just about artists starving. it‚Äôs about **culture rotting**. our games, our films, the stories we love, reduced to corporate slop, endlessly remixed, endlessly empty.

they call this the future? a world where every image, every frame, every melody is a cheap algorithmic knockoff? where beauty is measured in clicks, not craft? where the only thing thriving is the machine‚Äôs ability to mimic what it never feels?

AI should be a tool, not a replacement. a brush in the artist‚Äôs hand, not the corporate axe over their neck. But unless we fight back, unless we refuse to swallow this synthetic mediocrity, the damage will be done. The flood won‚Äôt stop. And we‚Äôll all drown in the same derivative, algorithmically generated wasteland.

Is this really the world we want? Or will we finally say: enough?

Author: shiawase6946
Content:
We just see the rise of AI (LLM) use from the release of ChatGPT on Nov 2022. 2023 is more of expansion of AI use cases. Use of AI start skyrocketed on 2024 until now.

What I've observed was AI definitely kills translation jobs. Around 2020-2023, most of the translation jobs was only MTPE (Machine Translation Post Editing). In one document, It was like around 80% of the texts need to be translated manually by people. After MTPE, usually the amount of texts that needs to be translated reduced to only like 20%. So it was like 60% paycheck reduced for freelance translators.

Naturally, in recent years, MTPE jobs is also reduced in number as AI getting more advanced by being fed with feedback from MTPE.

Translation jobs was text-based, and AI has reduced the needs for the service significantly. Of course since AI now has ability to produce Image and Video, digital artists would feel threatened.

Author: shiawase6946
Content:
For context. Translation jobs are separated into two: translation and localization. Translation mostly deal with texts that did not require much 'creative' force as it usually has a very defined context and use case. They are texts like manuals, business documents, technical documents and subtitles.

Localization deals with more fluid context so it needs more creative force. Texts like copywriting, novels, and poems.

Those in the first category are already a lost cause.

Author: shiawase6946
Content:
Of course digital artists would feel very uneasy with AI. It is like how translation jobs used to be. The numerous low-to-mid skill level jobs that used to exist to cater to small-chunks of myriad of organizations need in their marketing and documentations are gone eaten by AI.

Tell them to upskill? These organizations do not need high-skill translator to translate their machine manuals and internal documents, plus they do not want to pay more. Upskill then look for high-skill translation job? The supply would kill the demand.
